section.name: Determined the purpose/context of the argument or conclusion that needed to be made.

values.desc: No evidence
Minimally
Partially
Completely

values.name: a
values.desc: Identified the question that needed to be answered or the situation that needed to be addressed.

values.name: b
values.desc: Identified any situational factors that may be important for addressing the question or situation.

values.name: c
values.desc: Identified the general types of data or information needed to address the question.
Review the instructions or general goal of the task.
highlight or clearly state the question to be addressed or type of conclusion that must be reached.
List the factors (if any) that may limit the feasibility of some possible conslusions.
Write down the information you think is needed to address the situation.

section.name: Determined the relevance and reliability of information that might be used to support the conclusion or argument

values.desc: No evidence
Minimally
Partially
Completely

values.name: a
values.desc: Indicated what information is likely to be most relevant

values.name: b
values.desc: Determined the reliability of the source of information

values.name: c
values.desc: Determined the quality and accuracy of the information itself
Review provided material and circle, highlight, or otherwise indicate information that may be used as evidence in reaching a conclusion.
Write down other information (prior knowledge) that might be useful to lead to/support a possible conclusion.
Set aside any information, patterns, or insights that seem less relevant to addressing the situation at hand.
Consider whether the relevant information was obtained from a reliable source (textbook, literature, instructor, websites with credible authors)
Determine the quality of the information and whether it is sufficient to answer the question.

section.name: Interpreted information to determine meaning and to extract relevant evidence

values.desc: No evidence
Inaccurately
With some errors
Accurately

values.name: a
values.desc: Discussed data/information and explored possible meanings

values.name: b
values.desc: Identified general trends or patterns in the data/information that could be used as evidence

values.name: c
values.desc: Processed and/or transformed data/information to put it in forms that could be used as evidence
Interpret and label key pieces of information in text, tables, graphs, diagrams.
State in your own words what information represents or means.
Identify general trends in information and note any information that doesn’t fit the pattern.
Check your understanding of information with others and discuss any differences in understanding.
State how each piece of information, pattern, or insight can be used to reach a conclusion or support your claim.

section.name: Connected or integrated information to support an argument or reach a conclusion

values.desc: No evidence
Inaccurately
With some errors
Accurately

values.name: a
values.desc: Identified the relationships between different pieces of information or concepts

values.name: b
values.desc: Compared or contrasted what could be determined from different pieces of information

values.name: c
values.desc: Combined multiple pieces of information or ideas in valid ways to generate a new insight or conclusion
Look for two or more pieces or types of information that can be connected and state how they can be related to each other.
Write out the aspects that are similar and different in various pieces of information.
Map out how the information and/or concepts can be combined to support an argument or reach a conclusion.
Write a statement that summarizes the integration of the information and conveys a new understanding.
List the ways in which synthesized information could be used as evidence.

section.name: Made an argument that includes a claim (a position), supporting information, and reasoning.

values.desc: No evidence
Minimally
Partially
Completely

values.name: a
values.desc: Stated the conclusion or the claim of the argument

values.name: b
values.desc: Listed the evidence used to support the argument

values.name: c
values.desc: Linked the conclusion/claim to the evidence with focused and organized reasoning

values.name: d
values.desc: State any qualifiers that limit the conditions for which the argument is true
Review the original goal ‐ what question were you trying to answer?
Clearly state your answer to the question (your claim or conclusion).
Review the information you previously evaluated, analyzed and/or synthesized and decide what evidence supports your claim.
List each piece of evidence that you are using to support your argument.
Explain how each piece of information links to and supports your answer.
Make sure that your answer includes the claim, information and reasoning.
Make sure that the claim or conclusion answers the question

section.name: The claim, evidence, and reasoning were logical and consistent with broadly accepted principles.

values.desc: No evidence
Minimally
Partially
Fully

values.name: a
values.desc: The most relevant evidence was used appropriately to support the claim

values.name: b
values.desc: Reasoning was logical and effectively connected the data to the claim

values.name: c
values.desc: The argument was aligned with disciplinary/community concepts or practices

values.name: d
values.desc: Considered alternative or counter claims

values.name: e
values.desc: Considered evidence that could be used to refute or challenge the claim
Provide a clear statement that articulates why the evidence you chose leads to the claim or conclusion.
Check to make sure that your reasoning is consistent with what is accepted in the discipline or context.
Test your ideas with others and ask them to judge the quality of the argument or indicate how the argument could be made more convincing.
Ask yourself (and others) if there is evidence or data that doesn't support your conclusion or might contradict your claim.
Consider if there are alternative explanations for the data you are considering.
